titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Roger W. Moss Collection of Manuscript, Original Art and Printed Material by and about Richard Shirley Smith
Moss (Roger W.) Collection of Manuscript, Original Art and Printed Material by and about Richard Shirley Smith

did.unittitle: Roger W. Moss Collection of Manuscript, Original Art and Printed Material by and about Richard Shirley Smith

repository.corpname: Yale Center for British Art, Rare Books and Manuscripts

did.abstract: The collection comprises manuscripts, original art and printed material by and about Richard Shirley Smith, collected by Roger W. Moss.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The collection is the physical property of the Yale Center for British Art. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the Curator of Rare Books and Manuscripts.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Roger W. Moss Collection of Manuscript, Original Art and Printed Material by and about Richard Shirley Smith, Yale Center for British Art, Gift of Roger W. Moss.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into six series: I. Books and Articles on Richard Shirley Smith; II. Publications Designed or Illustrated by Richard Shirley Smith; III. Engraved and Drawn Bookplates by Richard Shirley Smith; IV. Engravings by Richard Shirley Smith; V. Ephemera; VI. Correspondence. Arrangement follows, to the extent possible, that of the checklist by Roger W. Moss.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection comprises manuscripts, original art and printed material by and about Richard Shirley Smith, collected by Roger W. Moss. A description of the collection is provided in the forward to Moss's checklist, Richard Shirley Smith: illustrated books, engravings and bookplates: annotated checklist, Roger W. Moss Collection (Marlborough, England : Libanus Press, 2010):

blockquote.p: This checklist of Richard Shirley Smith's illustrated books, engravings and bookplates is intended to compliment lain Bain's Wood Engravings of Richard Shirley Smith (Cambridge, 1994), Shirley Smith's Paintings & Collages (London, 2002), and Brian North Lee's Bookplates by Richard Shirley Smith (Fleece Press, 2005). It also documents my own collection begun after I commissioned Shirley Smith to produce a millennium year ex libris for books acquired by an endowment in my name at The Athenaeum of Philadelphia. Since I could never hope to own more than a few of his paintings and none of his trompe l'oeil murals--many of which are in privately-owned country houses--I focused on the books he has illustrated over the past half century. Eventually I added original strikes of virtually all the engravings and bookplates as well, including items unrecorded by Iain Bain and Brian North Lee. From the beginning the collection was destined for an appropriate institution in the United States where the work of this versatile artist is not as well known as it should be. In England collections of Shirley Smith's engravings already exist at the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford and also in London at the British Museum and the Victoria & Albert Museum. The Bodleian Library have asked to receive his main archive.

Richard Shirley Smith was born in London (1935) and educated at Harrow and the Slade School of Fine Art. After a year and a half of further study in Rome, he returned to England in 1962 to support his young family as a freelance graphic designer for commercial publishers. Richard was not encouraging when I began to collect these early books, preferring that I concentrate on the finely printed limited editions of his mature work. But these early commissions paid the bills and gave him practical experience in book design and publishing. Most were for dust jackets, but occasionally he was asked to illustrate an entire book. He produced fifty drawings for Wilfrid Blunt's Of Flowers & A Village (Hamish Hamilton, 1963), and for each of the nine biographies of musicians by Percy M. Young published by Ernest Benn he provided at least a dozen drawings that ranged from portraits to landscapes and architecture. Fortunately for his later career, some publishers recognized the exceptional quality of his wood engravings, which were far more tedious and time consuming to produce than the mono-types and drawings typically commissioned. Shirley Smith's engraved portrait of Sir Thomas More set against a detailed London background, for example, was commissioned by Burns & Oates and used for several of Ernest Edwin Reynolds's books published in both England and the United States.

It was the art directors at Faber and Faber who particularly favoured Shirley Smith's wood engravings. Ten of these appeared in their edition of Douglas Bartrum's The Gourmet's Garden (1964) and another ten in Elizabeth Clarke's The Darkening Green (1964). The discipline of working against a publisher's deadline for a set of ten original engravings would be valuable experience in the future.

Often a catalogue raisonné--or even a simple, chronological checklist such as this one--illuminates important turning points in an artist's career. For Richard Shirley Smith, 1967 stands out. In that year, seventeen of his wood engravings dating from his studies in Rome were featured by The Golden Head Press in a slim volume of Joyce Finzi's poetry; The Folio Society published thirty of his wood engravings commissioned for their limited edition of Sir Roger de Coverly ; and in New York, Macmillan released Memoirs of a London Doll illustrated with fifteen commissioned wood engravings.

The 1967 projects prompted the typographical advisor and historian John Dreyfus (1918-2002), who was an agent for the Limited Editions Club in the United States, to suggest Shirley Smith as the illustrator for Stephen Spender's selection of Shelley's poems which was published in 1971. For this commission he executed forty-six wood engravings. Of this project Richard wrote: 'I think ... this was my "masterpiece" as regards engraving' and John Dreyfus would later remark, Shirley Smith 'was able to render intricate details of architecture, landscape, seascape, flora, fauna and the human face--all with equal mastery and with astonishing control of perspective and the lighting of the different planes.' Laurence Whistler, brother of Rex Whistler, and an artist who recognized genius when he encountered it, wrote 'here is an artist whose scope is not narrow. With equal skill he handles the charming simplicities of doll's house furniture, portraits, houses, food, insects, animals, flowers--and scenes of imagination. In the end it is the last-named that catch and hold the attention. He seems to have discovered his true gift while interpreting, or simply responding to, poetry.'

Shirley Smith had left behind his journeyman work as an engraver and illustrator for commercial publishers. Henceforth he would be in demand by The Folio Society, Oxford University Press, and private press publishers such as Libanus, Rocket, Fleece, and Gruffyground which featured his engravings, line drawings, and paintings in finely bound, limited and signed editions, including such publications as Hugh Shankland's Messer Pietro Mio (1985). Concurrently, several well publicized exhibitions such as his fiftieth birthday retrospective at the Ashmolean Museum and the Royal Institute of British Architects, and several books and articles that are listed in the first section of this checklist have helped to create a steady demand for his easel paintings, murals and fine and limited edition book illustrations.

Since that modest commission to design my book plate, Richard Shirley Smith and I have developed a cordial trans-Atlantic friendship that has given me considerable pleasure. Without his cooperation and encouragement neither the collection nor this publication would have been possible. Roger W. Moss, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

did.unittitle: Books and Articles on Richard Shirley Smith

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Descriptions in this series are copied, with minor changes, from the Roger W. Moss annotated checklist (with the author's kind permission), reproducing the item enumeration and descriptive conventions used in the checklist. Formatting is modified.

For each item, a parallel record is included the Yale University Library catalog, and links to the records are provided herewith; the catalog records describe the material according to standard library cataloging conventions.

For each item, a parallel record is included the Yale University Library catalog, and links to those records are provided herewith; these records describe the material according to standard library cataloging conventions.

did.unittitle: Prospect: The Schweppes Book of the New Generation. London: Hutchinson, 1962.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Set in Bembo type and printed by The Anchor Press, Ltd., Tiptree, Essex, on a special smooth wove paper; colour plates printed by L. Van Leer & Company, Netherlands. Pages 193-197 devoted to Richard Shirley Smith with reproductions of five wood engravings [Bain nos. 28-32]. Bound in olive-brown book cloth with dust jacket designed by David Gentleman.
Inclusion in Roger Bannister's Prospect was Shirley Smith's first national recognition as an emerging artist of talent.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: "Bookplate Designs by Richard Shirley Smith." The Private Library 10 (Summer, 1977).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With reproductions of six bookplates: Timothy Harman [1962, Bain no. 33, North Lee no. 3], Jacob Rothschild [1973, Bain no. 215, North Lee no. 9], John Retallack [1974, Bain no. 232, North Lee no.11], James Ley Wilson [1974, Bain no. 231, North Lee no. 10], Michael J. Mitchell [1975, Bain no. 236, North Lee no. 13], and Sir George Taylor [1974, Bain no. 233, North Lee no. 12] and four engraved labels: ASHMANSWORTH/ NR NEWBURY * BERKS * [c.1962, for Joyce Finzi, not in Bain], NIGEL FINZI [c.1962, not in Bain], DR ALEC HAY/ 9 WOODSTOCK ROAD/BEDFORD PARK/LONDON .W.4 [c. 1962, not in Bain], and PAX for Valentine Ackland [1962, Bain no. 35]. Sewn soft cover.

The British bookplate scholar Brian North Lee (1936-2007) became aware of Richard Shirley Smith's engraved bookplates in the early 1970s and his several publications on Shirley Smith spanning nearly twenty years (here listed together in chronological order) brought that branch of his art to the attention of an international audience.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Richard Shirley Smith und Seine Holzstich–ExLibris, Österreichsches Jahrbuck für ExLibris und Gebrauchsgraphik Jahrgang 1981–1983 . Vienna, 1983.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Article on pages 74-79 with reproductions of five bookplates: Michael Riviere [1978, Bain no. 241, North Lee no. 14], Auberon Waugh [1978, Bain no. 242, North Lee no. 15], Amanda Karen Petford [1979, Bain no. 244, North Lee no. 17], P. & D. Colnaghi [1980, Bain no. 246, North Lee no. 18], and Adrian Sassoon [1980, Bain no. 248, North Lee no. 20]. Several bookplates by other artists are tipped in. Sewn soft binding. North Lee's copy with his ex libris.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Richard Shirley Smith Fiftieth Birthday Retrospective Exhibition. Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, and Royal Institute of British Architects Heinz Gallery, London W1. Sponsored by the Landseer Property Corporation. Privately printed, 1985.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes essays by Henry Ford on Shirley Smith's paintings, collages & murals; a retrospective catalogue; Shirley Smith as a wood engraver by Brian North Lee; a catalogue of engravings, 1960-1984; and a chronology. Sewn soft binding.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: "Richard Shirley Smith" in Artur Mário da Mota Miranda, Encyclopaedia Bio-Bibliographical of the Art of the Contemporary Ex-Libris. Portugal: Editorial Franciscana, 1986.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Edition limited to 500 numbered copies of which this is no. 41. Article appears on pages 159-174 with photograph and reproductions of seventeen bookplates. Also includes a 'Checklist of Ex-Libris by Richard Shirley Smith' with descriptions of thirty-three bookplates through 1984. Bound in red book cloth. Shirley Smith's copy with his studio ex libris.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: "Richard Shirley Smith." Ex Libris: Rivista Italiana di Xilografia Ex Libris e Piccola Grafica. Milan, 1987.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Article appears on pages 94-97 with reproductions of eight bookplates: John Loch [1983, Bain no. 254, North Lee no. 23], Iain Bain [1983, Bain no. 253, North Lee no. 22], Brian North Lee [1984, Bain no. 259, North Lee no. 26], John D. N. Retallack [1974, Bain no. 232, North Lee no. 11], Benoît Junod [1983, Bain no. 256, North Lee no. 25], Jacob Rothschild [1973, Bain no. 215, North Lee no. 9], David J. Profumo [1984, Bain no. 363, North Lee no. 30], and Raymond & Pamela Lister [1984, Bain no. 262, North Lee no. 29]. Stapled soft binding. Shirley Smith's copy with his studio ex libris.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: My Personal Bookplates . Published by Brian North Lee and Printed by Pardy & Son, Ltd., Ringwood, Hampshire, 2001.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Illustrations of bookplates by Joan Hassall, Reynolds Stone, Leo Wyatt, Mark Severin, John Lawrence, Richard Shirley Smith [1984, Ex Libris for Brian North Lee, Bain no.259, North Lee no. 26], Roy Cooney, Hilary Paynter and others. Extra-illustrated with four bookplates tipped in. Stapled soft binding. Shelved together with 'The Bookplate Library of Brian North Lee,' Claude Cox Catalogue 178, Ipswich (Summer, 2007) offering 735 items.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Bookplates by Richard Shirley Smith. Printed and published by Simon Lawrence at his Fleece Press, Upper Denby, Huddersfield, 2005 [2006].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Colophon reads: 'There are 275 copies of this book, and it has been a pleasure to print some of the very best bookplates ever made. Of these, forty copies (thirty-two for sale) contain a chemise holding four proofs of drawn bookplates, signed by the artist. The paper is T. H. Saunders HP, the type Van Dijck set at Whittington by Peter Pugwash Sanderson, and the reproductions of the bookplates were printed by Smith Settle, who also bound the book.' This is one of the 32 copies with four drawn bookplates [North Lee nos. 36, 40, 43, 52] signed and dated by Shirley Smith. Quarter bound in tan book cloth, boards covered in wood-grain paper; the clamshell box is covered in matching cloth lined with wood-grain paper. Note to Roger W. Moss from Simon Lawrence, The Fleece Press, laid in. Booklet 'More Fleece Press Books for 2005' (printed in an edition limited to 1200 copies) also laid in.

This lavish catalogue of Shirley Smith's bookplates produced through 2003 was one of North Lee's last publications; in it he assigned numbers to the bookplates that are used throughout this checklist. For Shirley Smith's bookplates created after 2003 the numbering sequence has been continued. See bookplate list (Section III).
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Engelse grafici: Joan Hassall, Alan Reynolds Stone, Leo Wyatt, Richard Shirley Smith. Sint-Niklaas, Belgium: Internationaal Exlibriscentrum. Catalogue for an exhibition held March 4-April 9, 1978.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: List of Shirley Smith engravings [nos. 213-272 in exhibition], photograph and 10 wood engravings are reproduced: Jacob Rothschild bookplate [1973, Bain no. 215, North Lee no. 9], John Retallack bookplate [1974, Bain no. 232, North Lee no. 11], 'Butterflies on Flower' [1971, Shelley, Bain no. 174], 'Portrait of Erasmus' [1965, Bain no. 82], 'Cove House for Giles FitzHerbert' [1973, Bain no. 230], 'Two Women' [1973, Chesterfield, Letters, Bain nos. 217-228], Memoirs of a London Doll [1967, Bain nos. 116-131], George Taylor bookplate [1974, Bain no. 233, North Lee no. 12], 'Grasshopper' [1971, Shelley, Bain no. 175]. Stapled soft binding. Invitation to exhibition laid in.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: A History of British Wood Engraving. Tunbridge Wells, Kent: Midas Books, 1978.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Set in monotype Plantin by South Bucks Typesetters, Ltd., Beaconsfield; printed and bound by R. J. Acford, Chichester, Sussex. Biography of Richard Shirley Smith on pp. 397-398 with reproductions of one engraving from Cupid's Progress, The Periodical on p. 308 [1970, Bain no. 163] and four engravings from Lord Chesterfield's Letters to His Son on p. 319 [1973, Bain nos. 217, 218, 226, 227]. Bound in gray book cloth with dust jacket.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Sixteen Contemporary Wood Engravers. A collection of wood engravings printed from the original blocks to accompany an exhibition. Newcastle, David Esslemont, 1982.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Foreword by Anthony Tuck and Dudley Wilson. 'This book was designed and printed by David Esslemont on a Columbian press. The edition consists of 250 copies on Zerkall mould-made paper. This copy is no. 126.' Signed by Esslemont. Each engraving is printed on a single page without text. Wood engravings by Leslie Benenson, Simon Brett, Clair Dalby, David Esslemont, Anne Jope, Simon King, John Lawrence, Angela Lemaire, Garrick Palmer, Hilary Paynter, Monica Poole, Peter Reddick, Michael Renton, Richard Shirley Smith [p. 14], George Tute and Sarah Van Niekerk. The colophon includes a printed ex libris for Dudley Wilson by Leo Wyatt as a tribute to the artist who had just died. Sewn soft binding. Prospectus laid in.

Shirley Smith is here represented by his mildly erotic wood engraving 'Thais'. Bain assigns it no. 257 for its appearance in David Burnett's Vines (1984), although it clearly predates that printing. The exhibition which this collection of wood engravings accompanied was a tribute to the growing interest in wood engraving in the North East of England. It was a joint venture sponsored partly by the Durham Light Infantry Museum and Arts Centre and partly by Collingwood College in the University of Durham.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Wood Engravings: Richard Shirley Smith a selection, 1960 to 1977. Printed by David Chambers at Cuckoo Hill Press, 1983.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Limited edition of 187 copies; seven copies printed on Hosho and 180 copies printed on Basingwerk Parchment of which this is copy no. 50 signed by Shirley Smith. Quarter bound in leather with gray buckram boards in gray buckram slipcase. Three cards announcing the publication laid in.

This first retrospective of Shirley Smith's wood engravings is by Sir Laurence Whistler (1912-2000), the brother of Rex Whistler (1905-1944), who remarks, 'It needs only a glance through these pages to discover that here is an artist whose scope is not narrow. With equal skill he handles the charming simplicities of doll's house furniture, portraits, houses, food, insects, animals, flowers—and scenes of imagination. In the end it is the last-named that catches and holds the attention. He seems to have discovered his true gift while interpreting, or simply responding to, poetry.'
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: "Profile of an Artist: Richard Shirley Smith." The Bookplate Journal III (March, 1985)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photograph and reproduction of the Timothy Harman bookplate [1962, Bain no. 33; North Lee no. 3].
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: "The Painter as Wood Engraver: Richard Shirley Smith and His Studio." The Green Book (Autumn, 1985).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reproductions include the Brian North Lee bookplate [1977, Bain no. 259] and five other engravings: two from The Poems of Percy Bysshe Shelley: 'Keats's Deathmask in Rome' [1971, Bain no. 167] and 'Shelley at Baths of Caracalla' [1971, Bain no. 165]; 'Portrait of Pépé' [1980, Bain no. 245]; 'Triumph of Death' [1985, Messer Pietro Mio, Bain no. 279]; and 'Two Fantastics' [1984, Bain no. 283]. Sewn soft binding. Prospectus for The Green Book illustrated with 'Two Fantastics' laid in.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: A Catalogue of Fine Press Printers in the British Isles. Oxford: Inky Parrot Press, 1986.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typeset by John Rose in 11-point Plantin on a CCRTronic phototypesetter, printed litho by Parchment (Oxford), Ltd., and bound by Paperback Binders (Oxford), Ltd. The text pages are printed on 140gsm Kaskad Pintail Cream and Kestrel Corn used for the endpapers. The cover is printed on 350gsm Kaskad Lapwing Brown from Robert Horne Paper Company, Ltd. Richard Shirley Smith's 'Cornucopias' [1985, Messer Pietro Mio, Bain no. 268] illustrates the paragraph describing Michael Mitchell's Libanus Press on page 27. Glued soft binding.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Second Conference of Fine Press Printing. November 22, 1986

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Conference program illustrated with wood engravings, including three by Richard Shirley Smith: 'Hands' [1985, Messer Pietro Mio, Bain no. 266], 'Girl's Head' [1984, Vines, Bain no. 258], 'Dark Tower' [1961, A Point of Departure, Bain no. 23]. Folded sheets.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Painting Murals: Images, Ideas and Techniques. London: Macdonald Orbis, Macdonld & Co. (Publishers), Ltd., 1987.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Filmset by Bookworm Typesetting, printed and bound in Spain by Graficromo SA. Three murals by Richard Shirley Smith reproduced on pp. 63, 93 and 136.

Like Caroline Cass's book on murals (no. 20 below), Patricia Seligman's Painting Murals was reissued in the United States in both hardback and paperback editions. Unfortunately she did not identify Shirley Smith's murals by name or location.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Engravers: A Handbook for the Nineties. Introduction by Simon Brett. Cambridge: Silent Books, 1987.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reproduces eight of Shirley Smith's wood engravings: 'Girl's Head' [1984, Vines, Bain no. 258], 'Head of Pan' [1971, Shelley, Bain no. 183], 'Altar' [1985, Messer Pietro Mio, Bain no. 267], 'Triumph of Death' [1985, Messer Pietro Mio, Bain no. 279], 'Decorative Rule' [1965, Folio Society, Bain no. 80], 'Wreathed Urn' [1971, Shelley, Bain no. 182], 'Heart Pendant' [1985, Messer Pietro Mio, Bain no. 281], and 'Rhinoceros Beetle' [1978, Buzz Buzz, Bain no. 151]. Perfect bound paperback.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Engravers: Two. A Handbook Compiled for the Society of Wood Engravers. Introduction by Simon Brett. Cambridge: Silent Books, 1992.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Expanded edition of the above [no. 18] with the same Shirley Smith engravings reproduced. Perfect bound paperback.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Grand Illusions: Contemporary Interior Murals. Oxford: Phaidon Press, 1988.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Shirley Smith's murals illustrated . 25, 38-39, 43, 61, 152. Bound in gray book cloth with dust jacket.

Caroline Cass's survey of contemporary murals, like Patricia Seligman's book the year before (no.17 above), was published in both England and the United States in several hardback and paperback editions. Here Shirley Smith's trompe l'oeil murals, the first of which he executed in 1976 for owners of the Doric Villa in Regent's Park, were properly credited.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: The Wood Engravings of Richard Shirley Smith. Cambridge: Silent Books, 1994.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typeset by Libanus Press, Marlborough; printed at The Alden Press, Osney Mead, Oxford. Limited to one hundred copies of which this is no. 27 signed by Shirley Smith. Photograph and one hundred twenty wood engravings reproduced with two signed and numbered prints in a chemise: 'Temple of Antoninus & Faustina, Rome' [1961, Bain no. 8] and 'Angel Visits Anna and Joachim, Rome' [1961, Bain no. 6]. Bound in dark red book cloth with paper-covered boards printed with reproductions of Shirley Smith engravings. Dark red slip case.

Included here is a catalogue of the engravings 1960 to 1989, a listing of exhibitions, illustrated books, and illustrated periodical & newspaper articles. Bain also assigned the numbers to Shirley Smith's wood engravings that are used throughout this checklist. However, several early engravings are omitted from Bain's list. See engravings list (Section IV).
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: The Wood Engravings of Richard Shirley Smith. Cambridge: Silent Books, 1994.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Trade paperback edition of above.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: "Still Life with Marble Foot." The Ashmolean 33 (Christmas, 1997)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Report on the acquisition of Shirley Smith's acrylic painting of that name commissioned in honor of Anne Stevens's service to the museum. The Ashmolean Museum of Art and Archaeology in Oxford has also acquired a complete set of Shirley Smith's wood engravings.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Folio 50. A Bibliography of The Folio Society 1947-1996 compiled by Paul W. Nash with essays by Sue Bradbury, Valerie Grove, Frank Delaney, Robertson Davies, Douglas Martin, Charles Ede, Quentin Blake, Roderick Cave and Paul W. Nash. London: The Folio Press, 1997, in association with The British Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typeset in Monotype Postscript Bembo by The Folio Society. Text printed at St Edmundsbury Press, Bury St Edmunds, on Hamilton Wove paper. Color plates printed at Barwell Colourprint, Midsomer Norton, on Sovereign Matt Cartridge paper. Bound in blue-gray book cloth at Hunter & Foulis, Edinburgh. Slipcase collage by Paul W. Nash. Richard Shirley Smith illustrated five books for The Folio Society prior to 1996, including Sir Richard de Coverly (1967) [no. 233; page 129]; Philip Stanhope (1973) [no. 327; page 152]; Robert Browning, Dramatic Monologues (1991) [no. 689; page 240]; Perfect and Imperfect Enjoyments (1992) [no. 725; page 252]; and Ovid, Metamorphoses (1995) [no. 812; page 275]. In each instance the citation in Folio 50 is accompanied by a reproduction of one Shirley Smith illustration for the book, including a full page from the Ovid on page 277. Shirley Smith subsequently contributed to four books for The Folio Society: prints for The Folio Golden Treasury designed by Simon Brett (1997); cover designs for Shakespeare, Complete Plays (1997); frontispiece and 21 line drawings for Virgil, The Ecologues (2000); and cover design for Carcopino, Daily Life in Ancient Rome (2004).
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: "Living National Treasures: Bookplate Artists." Country Life (January 7, 1999)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photograph of Richard Shirley Smith in his studio surrounded by examples of his bookplates.

Amicia de Moubray comments that Shirley Smith's bookplates have a 'delicate 18th -century Rococo quality, reminiscent of Rex Whistler…they often incorporate scrolls, volutes, coats of arms and delicately drawn vegetation. Primarily an artist known for murals, paintings and illustrations, Mr. Shirley Smith has been designing bookplates for more than 30 years.'
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Richard Shirley Smith. Exhibition catalogue for Chris Beetles, Ltd., 8 & 10 Ryder Street, St James's, London, 1999.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Twenty-six paintings and wood engravings illustrated (some in color) from the eighty-three items for sale. Includes essay by David Wootton, 'Richard Shirley Smith: Classic–Romantic Artist–Craftsman' and 'Richard Shirley Smith: a Selective Chronology.' Stapled soft binding.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Recent Acquisitions 1998. Harrow, Middlesex: Old Speech Room Gallery, Harrow School, 1999.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Color cover reproduction of 'Archaeological Fragments' (1986 acrylic painting; item 40 in the catalogue). Detailed discussion of items nos. 25-45 by Richard Shirley Smith purchased for Harrow School collection. Stapled soft binding. Shirley Smith attended Harrow School, 1949-1954.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: The Paintings & Collages, 1957 to 2000. Preface by Roy Strong. London: John Murray in association with Studio House, 2002.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Limited edition of 140 copies signed and numbered by Shirley Smith of which this is copy no. 82. Contained in a chemise are two wood engravings dating to 1961 signed and numbered by Shirley Smith: 'A Winter Night' and 'The Dark Tower,' both of which were first published in A Point of Departure by Joyce Finzi [Bain nos. 13 and 23]. Quarter bound in dark gray book cloth with decoratively printed boards and a light gray cloth-covered slipcase. Three items laid in: color prospectus for the publication; limited edition order form; and special pre-publication order form with note on verso to Roger W. Moss from Shirley Smith concerning the satisfactory reproduction of two acrylic paintings from his collection reproduced in the book.

Sir Roy Strong remarks, 'Shirley Smith's wood engravings fit neatly into the world of Rex Whistler and Reynolds Stone, and are quite as fine as anything produced by either of them. The bookplates make a distinguished contribution to that genre: delightful masterpieces in miniature, deploying his usual architectural repertory of urns, altars and fragments of friezes through and over which sprout greenery and flowers.'
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: The Paintings & Collages, 1957 to 2000 [trade copy of the above in dust jacket]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Inscribed 'for Gail & Roger / Richard Shirley Smith 4 April mmii.'

While most important for its reproductions of Shirley Smith's paintings and collages and his carefully compiled list of 281 framed and three-dimensional works, this book also contains a useful chronology of his personal life and professional career up to 2000. Also listed are the main exhibitions, trompe l'oeil mural decorations, periodical articles, and illustrated reference books—many of which are included in this checklist. However, the list of illustrated books is incomplete due mainly to Shirley Smith's modestly concerning the journeywork of his early career.
This copy retained by donor. A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Richard Shirley Smith. Harrow, Middlesex: Old Speech Room Gallery, Harrow School, 14 February-5 May, 2003.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Exhibition catalogue with line-drawn cover by Shirley Smith and reproductions of two wood engravings: 'Churchyard' [1977, Bain no. 240] and bookplate for Benoît Junod [1983, Bain no. 256, North Lee no. 25]. Stapled soft cover. Laid in is Shirley Smith's article from Harrow: Portrait of an English School (London: Farringdon House, 2004) on Maurice Percival, Harrow Art Master, 1945-1954, who greatly influenced Shirley Smith.

Old Harrovian Shirley Smith was honored with a one-man exhibition of his paintings, engravings, designs for books and cartoons for mural decorations. Exhibition curator, Carolyn Leder, wrote the introduction.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Contemporary World Ex Libris. Philadelphia: The Athenæum of Philadelphia, 2006.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: American Society of Bookplate Collectors and Designers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Moss Book Fund at The Athenæum of Philadelphia [2000, North Lee no. 59] reproduced on front cover. Printed for the American Society of Bookplate Collectors and Designers exhibition at The Athenæum of Philadelphia, September-October, 2006. Stapled soft binding. A flyer on Athenæum book funds laid in.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Press A Bibliography 1972-2007. Chestnut Press, 2007.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Perfect bound soft cover. Inscribed by Mark Askam on the half title: 'To Richard [Shirley Smith] Love the engravings! Mark / 2nd proof edition (1 of 4 copies) This is an early reading proof––produced digitally of an as-yet-unfinished bibliography. It is not likely to get published in a hard-copy form, but is available as an internet resource.'

Richard Shirley Smith engravings illustrated three books for Anthony Baker's Gruffyground Press: James Reeves, The Closed Door (1976-77) nos. 5a and 5b; Six Hampshire Epitaphs (1978) nos. 6a and 6b; and John Heath-Stubbs, Buzz Buzz (1981) nos. 12a and 12b. Shirley Smith's engravings for Reeves and Heath-Stubbs are reproduced . 41 & 42. Several limited editions of Shirley Smith's engravings were also produced by Gruffyground Press: two editions of the engraving used for The Closed Door [Bain no. 239] (sixty strikes in all); two editions of the engraving used for Six Hampshire Epitaphs [Bain no.240] (one hundred strikes in all); and one edition of the engraving used for Buzz Buzz [Bain no. 251] (one hundred strikes in all). There was also a special run of The Closed Door engraving which Anthony Baker sent out as a Christmas greeting and a postcard version of the same engraving run by Michael Mitchell at the Libanus Press. Mitchell also printed the Buzz Buzz engraving as a Christmas greeting.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: The Gruffyground Press: A Bibliography. Hitchin, Hertfordshire, Chestnut Editions, 2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Inscribed 'For Roger Moss with best wishes Mark (Askam)' Following the Libanus Press publication of this checklist, Mark Askam sent RWM this copy of the enlarged edition supported by the Arts Council of Great Britain.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: The Clock of the Years. An Anthology of Writings on Gerald and Joy Finzi¸ Marking Twenty-Five Years of the Finzi Friends Newsletter. Foreword by Paul Spicer. Lichfield: Chosen Press, 2007.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typeset by Rolf Jordan in Linotype Janson and printed by Cromwell Press, Trowbridgem Wiltshire. Bound in dark red book cloth with dust jacket.

Richard Shirley Smith's long association with the Finzi family is commemorated here by the use of his 1961 wood engravings first published in Joy Finzi's A Point of Departure (1967) which are reproduced on pages 90, 92, 94, 97, 100, 102 and 220. Also included in this anthology is a reprint of Jeremy Dale Roberts's review of Shirley Smith's The Paintings and Collages which originally appeared in the Finzi Friends Newsletter [item 31 above]. Laid in are photocopies of the obituaries of Joy Finzi from The Telegraph (June 6, 1991), The Guardian (June 19, 1991), and Shirley Smith's reminiscences of her from Joy Finzi, 1907-1991: Tributes from her friends.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: "Wood–engraved Bookplates." Offprint from Matrix 27 (pages 76-81 in paper wrappers). The Whittington Press, 2007.

Profumo [1984, Bain no. 365, North Lee no. 30], Sir John Sykes [1996, North Lee no.48]. Inscribed 'for Roger Moss…Richard Shirley Smith.'
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Publications Designed or Illustrated by Richard Shirley Smith

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Descriptions in this series are copied, with minor changes, from the Roger W. Moss annotated checklist (with the author's kind permission), reproducing the item enumeration and descriptive conventions used in the checklist. Formatting is modified.

For each item, a parallel record is included the Yale University Library catalog, and links to the records are provided herewith; the catalog records describe the material according to standard library cataloging conventions.

did.unittitle: The Gourmet's Garden. London: Faber and Faber, Ltd., 1964.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed by Latimer Trend & Company, Ltd., Plymouth. First edition. 'With decorations by Richard Shirley-Smith' consisting of ten wood engravings [Bain nos. 44-53] used in various combinations on dust jacket, title page, and chapter heads. Bound in orange book cloth with dust jacket. This set of engravings would be reprinted in a limited edition in 1985, see entry no. 116.

Faber and Faber was the first commercial publisher fully to exploit the illustrative potential of Shirley Smith's wood engravings, as demonstrated by Bartrúm's Gourmet's Garden [entry no. 52] and Clark's The Darkening Green [entry no. 54].
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

This copy of Water & Life was sent to Shirley Smith by the London publisher Andre Deutsch with the commission to design a new dust jacket for a contemplated British edition. did.unittitle: A Point of Departure. Poems by Joyce Finzi with Wood Engravings Richard Shirley Smith. Cambridge: The Golden Head Press, 1967.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed by Crampton & Sons, Ltd., Sawston, Cambridge. First edition. Seventeen wood engravings [Bain nos. 11–27]. Detail of 'The Dark Tower' [Bain no. 23] used as a four side bleed on the front cover. Sewn soft binding.

While staying with Shirley Smith and his first wife in the hills east of Rome, Joyce Finzi, widow of the composer Gerald Finzi, was working on a collection of poems entitled 'The division of one is two'. These inspired this series of wood engravings which, without being direct illustrations, added a visual counter-point to the theme of departure which runs through the whole collection. This was the first publication of Shirley Smith's suite of Rome engravings created in 1961.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Sir Roger de Coverly by Joseph Addison, Sir Richard Steele & Eustace Budgell. Edited by John Hampden, with wood-engravings by Richard Shirley Smith. London: The Folio Society, 1967.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Set in 11-point monotype Baskerville and printed by Richard Clay at the Chaucer Press, Bungay, Suffolk. The illustrations consist of a frontispiece portrait of Addison and Steele and 30 wood-engraved head pieces [Bain nos. 85-115], one used at the opening of each essay. Shirley Smith also engraved a decorative rule, which is used beneath each head piece and on the title page. Bound by W. and J. Mackay in quarter brown buckram, marbled paper boards, green end papers. Brown slip case.

This book project––Shirley Smith's first for The Folio Society––would presage his later career as the illustrator of fine limited editions; it was also his first major commission for a large number of his engravings. The year 1967 would prove to be a turning point in his career.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Memoirs of a London Doll, written by Herself. New York: Macmillan Company, 1967.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Edited by Mrs Fairstar (Otherwise Mr Richard Henry Horne). Introduction and notes by Margery Fisher with four endpaper illustrations by Miss Margaret Gillies and additional engraved decorations by Richard Shirley Smith [Bain nos. 116-131]. First edition. Bound in white book cloth, over-printed to duplicate the dust jacket.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Garland, a little anthology of poetry and engravings. Cambridge: The Golden Head Press, 1968.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed by R. I. Severs, Ltd., of Cambridge on Basingwerk Parchment set in Scotch Roman. Limited edition of 275 copies. Includes Shirley Smith's engraving "The Candle" on page 15 [Bain no. 133]. Sewn soft cover.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: The Prince and the Puppeteer. A fairy story by J. C. Bretherton with engravings by Richard Shirley Smith. Salisbury: Compton Press, 1969.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The engravings [Bain nos. 137-142] were cut on lino and the edition limited to 1000 copies, 100 of which are signed by the author and engraver of which this is copy number no. 66. Stapled soft binding with semi-opaque protective cover.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: The Periodical. Oxford University Press, Spring, Summer, Autumn, Winter, 1970.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Four covers featuring wood engravings by Richard Shirley Smith. ["Cupid's Progress" Bain nos. 161-164]. Stapled soft covers.

did.unittitle: The Story of the Venetian Villas. London: Visual Publications, 1973.
did.physdesc: booklet 225 x 135 mm, box 240 x 160 x 55 mm

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of booklet containing a general introduction to the series of four filmstrips compiled, annotated and photographed by Shirley Smith (225 x 135 mm pp. 64) and a box (240 x 160 x 55 mm) holding four filmstrip canisters. The booklet has been quarter bound in black book cloth with marbled paper-cover boards.

In 1969 and 1970, while Shirley Smith was Head of the Art Department at Marlborough College, he travelled to the Vento to photograph art and architecture. A third expedition was made in 1971 and this set of four film strips was the result. While the effort was not a financial success, the experience of closely examining the works of Palladio, Veronese, and the sculptor Vittoria at such sites as Maser and the Villa Barbaro influenced his later murals and framed paintings.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: The Poems of Percy Bysshe Shelley. Selected, edited, and introduced by Stephen Spender Illustrated with wood engravings by Richard Shirley Smith. Cambridge: Limited Editions Club, 1971.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Designed by John Dreyfus and printed at the University Printing House in Cambridge by Brooke Crutchley, Printer to the University. Forty-six engravings [Bain nos. 165-210]. Edition of 1500 copies signed and numbered by Shirley Smith of which this is copy no. 793. Quarter bound in leather with orange book cloth boards impressed with oval relief (60 mm) portrait of Shelley. Slip case. A copy of The Monthly Letter of the Limited Editions Club (December, 1971, no. 450) laid in.

The Shelley project––commissioned by the Limited Editions Club in the United States in 1969 at the suggestion of John Dreyfus-- was printed in 1971 and reprinted by the Heritage Press in 1974. This was Shirley Smith's largest book project in terms of the number of commissioned wood engravings. He would later write, 'I think the word "masterpiece" originally referred to the piece of work, that divides the apprentice from the professional; in which case this was my "masterpiece" as regards engraving.' The Paintings & Collages, p. 10.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

unittitle.title: Wood engravings for Poems of Shelley by Richard Shirley Smith.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Boxed set of forty-two of the forty-six Shirley Smith engravings for the Shelley project [Bain nos. 165-206] printed on individual sheets of Japanese paper by the artist in a limited edition of 25 boxed sets, numbered and signed, of which this is set number seven. The 42 engravings have been individually matted and boxed. See engraving list (Section IV).
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: The Poems of Percy Bysshe Shelley. Selected, edited, and introduced by Stephen Spender Illustrated with wood engravings by Richard Shirley Smith. Norwalk, CT, Heritage Press, 1974.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Designed by John Dreyfus in 13 point monotype Bembo. Reprint of the Limited Editions Club edition of 1971. Bound in blue book cloth, front cover die-stamped with 55 x 44 mm stylized papyrus plant motif; endpapers printed with enlarged detail of Shirley Smith's 'Flowery Wreath' [Bain no. 180]. Slip case. A copy of the Heritage Club Sandglass describing The Poems of Shelley laid in.

There is a variant of the Heritage Press edition binding with plain white endpapers and boards printed with an enlarged detail in four-side bleed of 'Moths and Moon' [Bain no. 192]. There is no mention that this is a reprint of the Limited Editions Club edition.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: The Poems of Percy Bysshe Shelley. Selected, edited, and introduced by Stephen Spender Illustrated with wood engravings by Richard Shirley Smith. Norwalk, CT, The Easton Press, 1974.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Collector's Library of Famous Editions. Reprint (probably run with the Heritage Club edition) on cream-white vellum-finish paper from the Finch-Pruyn mill of Glen Falls, New York. Printed and bound by Lake Book, John F. Cuneo Co., Melrose Park, IL. Bound in gilt-stamped full maroon leather embossed with a floral pattern designed by George Herrick, gold moiré silk endpapers, satin marker ribbon and gilt edges. A copy of The Collector's Library of Famous Editions describing The Poems of Shelley laid in.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Philip Stanhope fourth Earl of Chesterfield, Letters to his Son. Selected, edited and introduced by James Harding, wood-engravings by Richard Shirley Smith. London: The Folio Society, 1973.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Chesterfield, Philip Dormer Stanhope, Earl of, 1694-1773

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The lithographic frontispiece reproduces William Hoare's painting of Stanhope c. 1743, now in the National Portrait Gallery. Set in 11-point monotype Baskerville with Old Face Open for display and printed in brown and black by W. and J. Mackay. Twelve wood-engraved head-and-shoulder portraits by Shirley Smith [Bain nos. 217-228], printed in pairs, in brown. Each is used twice, in a different combination, so there are twenty-four pairs in all. Bound by W. and J. Mackay in quarter black buckram with Cockerell marbled paper boards. Slip case.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Hero and Leander, a poem by David Burnett with engravings by Richard Shirley Smith. Printed privately by the Oxford University Press, 1975.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: First edition. Edition limited to 200 copies signed by the author and engraver of which this is no.192. Lino engravings cut in 1969 [Bain nos. 143-160]. Sewn soft cover with pink paper wrapper.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: The River Boy. Introduction by Lord David Cecil. London: Oxford University Press, 1976.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed by offset lithography by Billing & Sons, Ltd., Guildford, London and Worcester. 'Illustrated by Richard Shirley-Smith'. Line drawings [color dust jacket and sixteen drawings, some used multiple times]. Bound in golden yellow book cloth with dust jacket.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: The Closed Door. Sidcot, North Somerset: Gruffyground Press, 1977.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: First edition. Text handset in Walbaum, and printed letterpress in black and brown on handmade cream Twinrocker Sweetbutter paper by Claire van Vliet and Susan Johanknecht at Janus Press in Vermont. Richard Shirley Smith wood engraving of a mournful girl sitting on the floor [Bain no. 239]. Limited edition of 245 copies of which this is one of 165 copies reserved for the Gruffyground Press (Janus and Twinrocker divided the remaining 75 copies). Signed by Shirley Smith and James Reeves. Sewn soft cover of brown Fabriano Ingres paper. Extra print laid in (signed and numbered 4/60) by Shirley Smith. Also laid in an unsigned wood engraving by Simon Brett and a typed letter from Anthony Baker, the Press's proprietor, explaining the meaning of 'Gruffyground' and reporting James Reeves's death.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

unittitle.title: Baden Ian Dundonald Baker Born Rowberrow.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Somerset, March 29th, 1900 Died Axbridge, Somerset, January 18th, 1922' folded paper (150 x 100 mm) utilizing Richard Shirley Smith's wood engraving of a mournful girl [Bain no. 239]. Following the Libanus Press publication of the Moss checklist, Anthony Baker sent RWM a copy of this memorial to his father [see also 100a].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A keepsake illustrated by Richard Shirley Smith and printed at the Libanus Press, Hermitage, Berkshire. Quarto single sheet (302 x 211 mm). Colophon on verso reads: 'This broadside was printed at the Libanus Press, Hermitage, Berkshire, in November 1977, and is limited to one hundred and fifty copies signed by the engraver. This is No. 88.' The text is handset in 18- point Perpetua type, printed on dampened Amalfi white laid paper on the artist's Albion handpress of 1860. Wood-engraved portrait of Erasmus [1965; Bain no. 82] above two paragraphs from In Praise of Folly (1508) with Shirley Smith's engraved 'cone ribbons' logo for Libanus Press [Bain no. 235] on verso. In original Libanus Press envelope.

This keepsake marks the beginning of Richard Shirley Smith's long and fruitful association with Libanus Press. Michael Mitchell has been an important friend and collaborator over several decades. He exhibited Shirley Smith's work at his Katharine House Gallery, commissioned and published many of his illustrations and engravings, and expertly printed many of his books and bookplates.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Six Hampshire Epitaphs. Sidcot: Gruffyground Press, 1977.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Designed and printed in Bell type on an Albion press by George Tee at the Cernel Press, Cerne Abbas, Dorset. Published by Anthony Baker at the Gruffyground Press, Ladram, Sidcot, Winscombe, Somerset. The wood engraving on the title page is by Richard Shirley Smith ['Churchyard,' 1977; Bain no. 240]. 110 un-numbered copies printed on Portals mould-made paper and 20 un-numbered copies on Hosho handmade paper. Sewn with blue thread, into overlapping French-folded blue Mingei paper covers.

According to Mark Askam, Gruffyground Press: A Bibliography, 1972-2007 (see item no. 36 above), there were two issues of this item, neither of which met Anthony Baker's exacting standards of printing. Only a few copies were distributed.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Six Hampshire Epitaphs. Sidcot: Gruffyground Press, 1977.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sidcot: Gruffyground Press, 1977. Following the Libanus Press publication of the Moss Collection checklist, Mark Askam sent RWM one of the unbound copies of #100 which he called 'one of the better printed copies!'
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: "Coronation Rose Baker née Tooze, Born Oakford Bridge, Devon, April 30th, 1902 Died Sidcot, Somerset, April 24th, 1982."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folded paper 89 x 110 mm Utilizing Richard Shirley Smith's 'Churchyard' wood engraving [Bain no 240]. Sent to RWM by Anthony Baker who printed it as a memorial to his mother. Not in the Moss Collection printed checklist.

did.unittitle: Recalling the Goddess in Spring A.H. 1345. Libanus Press, Hermitage, Berkshire, 1978.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pp. [1-4] sewn into paper folder. Copy 35 of a numbered edition of 200 copies signed by the author. The text is handset in 18-point Perpetua type and printed on Vélin Arches pur chiffon creme paper, on a treadle platen press of 1895. Richard Shirley Smith wood engraved 'cone and ribbons' logo for Libanus Press [1975; Bain no. 235] used on cover and colophon page. Included in Libanus Press, Daylight Jobbery (1985), affixed to card 12.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Azrael & Other Poems. Libanus Press, Hermitage, Newbury, Berkshire, 1978.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: First edition, Crown Quarto. Printed in hand-set 18 point Perpetua Italic. Limited to 200 numbered copies, one half printed on T. H. Saunders paper, the other on French Vélin Arches paper of which this is copy no. 140. Richard Shirley Smith's 'cone and ribbons' Libanus Press logo [1975; Bain no. 235] used on the colophon page and on the prospectus produced by the press, a copy of which is laid in. Sewn soft cover of uncut Barcham Green paper.

According to the colophon, 'This collection of poems was first circulated in typescript by Sir Peter Pears at the Aldeburgh Festival in 1977. The author was approached for permission to print them in their present form and this was granted shortly before her death in May, 1978. This volume is dedicated to her memory.'
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Songs by Finzi & His Friends. Long-play record for the 25th Anniversary Celebration of Gerald Finzi's death in 1956. London, Hyperion, Ltd., 1981.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Drawn four-color sleeve (310 x 314 mm) illustrated and designed by Richard Shirley Smith.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Blewbury Festival Program of Events. June, 1981.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Richard Shirley Smith supplied the maps, many photographs, and designed this Blewbury, Oxfordshire, village festival brochure where he lived at the time. Stapled soft binding.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Buzz Buzz--Ten Insect Poems with a wood engraving by Richard Shirley Smith. The Gruffyground Press, Sidcot,1981.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Designed, handset in Bodoni italic, and printed on Vélin d'Arches mould-made paper by Michael Mitchell at the Libanus Press, Marlborough, Wiltshire, for Anthony Baker of the Gruffyground Press, Ladram, Sidcot, Winscombe, Somerset. Shirley Smith pearwood engraving [Rhinoceros Beetle on title page; Bain no. 251] printed from the original block. The Libanus Press logo by Shirley Smith also appears on the colophon page [1975; Bain no. 235]. The edition is limited to two hundred copies; one hundred copies are signed by Shirley Smith and John Heath-Stubbs. The cover is ochre Mingei handmade paper wrapper printed in black. Sewn soft binding.

According to Mark Askam, Gruffyground Press: A Bibliography, 1972-2007 (see item 36 above), John Heath-Stubbs wrote two slightly different versions of the poem 'Silverfish'. He could not decide which version to use, so it was decided that one half of the publication would be printed with one version of the poem and the other half with the other. In this copy, the end of line four in the first stanza of 'Silverfish' ends with 'Secondary Epoch'. Being completely blind, John Heath-Stubbs had to have his hand placed in the correct position on each colophon page in order to sign the copies. This accounts for the huge variation in his signatures and their most interesting, if rather illegible, nature.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Late in the Day. Hitchin, Herts: Mandeville Press, 2 Taylor's Hill, 1982.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 'An edition of 250 copies with a block from a wood-engraving ["The Candle"; Bain no. 133] by Richard Shirley Smith, of which 35 have been signed by the author' of which this is copy no. 18. Sewn soft cover.

did.unittitle: Vines. Poems by David Burnett wood engravings by Richard Shirley Smith. The Rocket Press, Steventon, Abingdon, Oxfordshire, 1984.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: First edition. Hand-set in Bell type and printed by Jonathan Stephenson at The Rocket Press on Zerkall mould-made paper. Bound with marbled paper from Compton Marbling and Richard de Bas hand-made endpapers. The edition is limited to 200 copies of which numbers 1 to 50 are hardbound with additional signed prints of the engravings, "Thais" and "Girl's Head" [Bain nos. 257 & 258] and numbers 51 to 200 are sewn into soft covers. This is number 32 of the 50 hardbound copies. Signed by Shirley Smith. The two engravings, signed and numbered xxxii/50, are each contained in individual folders with printed labels, all contained in a marbled-board slipcase. The poems are drawn from a larger collection entitled Thais. Six poems with images by Kenneth Lindley were published by the Pointing Finger Press of Hereford in a limited edition entitled Figures and Spaces in 1978 and a further fifty in Thais by the Black Cygnet Press of Durham in 1981.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Vines. Poems by David Burnett wood engravings by Richard Shirley Smith.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: The Cat: An Essay. Marlborough, Wiltshire: Libanus Press, 1984.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Set in monotype Joanna. Cover illustrations by Richard Shirley Smith [cropped cat head and seated cat detail from the Benoît Junod engraved bookplate [1975, Bain no. 256; Lee no. 25]. One of 1200 unnumbered copies printed on Basingwerk Parchment, sewn into overlapping card covers.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Daylight Jobbery: Ephemera to 1985. First collection of ephemera from the commercial printings of Libanus Press. Marlborough, Wiltshire: Libanus Press, 1985.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Twenty–six cards (310 x 223 mm), some with multiple samples affixed, plus index sheet. Includes eight items designed by or utilizing Richard Shirley Smith engravings. Seventy-five copies total. Clamshell box. Richard Shirley Smith's copy with his studio ex–libris.

#1. RSS drawn boarder Calthorpe wedding invitation #3. RSS invitation to viewing 27 November 1982 [Head of Pan from Poems of Shelley, 'Hymn of Pan,' Bain no. 183] #12. RSS wood engraving Elliot, Recalling Spring [Libanus Press logo, Bain no. 235]#13. RSS letterhead [no illustration] #14. RSS wood engraving for exhibition at Katharine House Gallery 17 October 1982 [Flowery Wreath from Poems of Shelley, 'Elegy on the Death of Adonis,' Bain no. 180] #17. RSS wood engraving for exhibition at Katharine House Gallery 29 May 1983 ['Contessina Emilia Viviani' from Poems of Shelley, 'Epipsychidion,' Bain no. 186] #23. RSS wood engraving for exhibition at Katharine House Gallery Christmas 1982 ['Flowers and Scull in Basket' from Poems of Shelley, title page, Bain no. 81] #24. RSS wood engravings for The Sapient Pig Wine List and Menu ['Apples and Pear,' Bain no. 74]
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Messer Pietro Mio. Letters between Lucrezia Borgia & Pietro Bembo. Marlborough, Wilshire: Libanus Press, 1985.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed in 14- point monotype Bembo on Barcham Green handmade Chester paper. Wood engravings by Richard Shirley Smith [Bain nos. 265-282]. Edition limited to 150 copies, numbered 1-135, and fifteen special copies with an extra set of prints identified as A-O. This is copy 54, signed by Shirley Smith. Bound in tan quarter morocco with embossed paper boards in slip case. Prospectus laid in.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Messer Pietro Mio. Marlborough, Wiltshire, Libanus Press, 28 July, 1985.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Boxed set of the seventeen wood engravings mounted in twelve window mats (302 x 258 mm); each signed by Richard Shirley Smith and numbered copy no. 23 of 100 copies and housed in a clamshell box covered in tan book cloth with pasted paper label 'Messer Pietro Mio The Engravings Richard Shirley Smith Libanus Press 1985' [Bain nos. 265-282]. Prospectus for the Messer Pietro Mio project together with a copy of Libanus Press, Book List for 1986 (4Pp.) laid in. The engravings for Messer Pietro Mio were cut between 1977 and 1985 and published in 1985. According to the prospectus the engravings reflect 'the metaphorical, heraldic and surreal elements contained in the letters.' They were the last major suite of wood engravings Shirley Smith produced before a detached retina at the age of fifty forced him to stop engraving and to concentrate on drawn images. According to Shirley Smith, only 30 of the projected 100 boxed sets of the engravings were actually assembled and distributed.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: The Prettiest Love Letters in the World. Letters between Lucrezia Borgia & Pietro Bembo. London: Collins Harvill, 1987.

A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: The Prettiest Love Letters in the World. Letters between Lucrezia Borgia & Pietro Bembo. Boston: David R. Godine, 1987.

did.unittitle: The Prettiest Love Letters in the World. Letters between Lucrezia Borgia & Pietro Bembo. Boston: David R. Godine, 1987.

did.unittitle: The Testament of Charlotte B. Marlborough, Wiltshire: Libanus Press, 1988.

did.unittitle: Surplus Pages from a Cross Section in 1988. Fleece Press, 1988.

did.unittitle: On Gardens. His Essay, taken from the first complete collection which was published in 1625, the year before his death. Libanus Press, 1989.

did.unittitle: The Spectator. Vol. 267, no 8528 (December 21/28, 1991).

did.unittitle: Perfect and Imperfect Enjoyments: poems by John Wilmot, Earl of Rochester. Introduction by Christopher Hibbert and illustrated with paintings by Richard Shirley Smith. London: The Folio Press, 1992.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Eight leaves of two-color lithographed plates [facingPp. 3, 19, 30, 52, 70, 89, 95 and 96]. Typeset in monotype Garamond. Printed on white Magnani mould-made paper by Stamperia Valdonega, Verona, Italy, photolithographic plates printed at the Senecio Press, Charlbury, Oxfordshire. Five hundred numbered copies printed of which 450 copies are quarter bound in Oasis morocco and 50 special copies are bound in full vellum with a separate portfolio of illustrations. In addition to the 500 numbered copies, 40 additional lettered copies (35 standards and five specials) were printed and bound for private distribution by the Society. This copy is signed and numbered 168/500. Bound by the Fine Bindery in quarter dark red morocco, Cockerell marbled paper boards; dark green endleaves. Dark green clamshell box, printed paper cover-label and leather spine-label. Folio Society color prospectus laid in.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: The Boke of Iford. Introduction by Robert Whalley. Marlborough, Wiltshire: Libanus Press, 1993.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Twelve drawings by Richard Shirley Smith, six of which are cappriccios encompassing the sculptural and architectural elements of the garden. Edition limited to 200 copies; twenty-five copies printed on Vélin Arches rag paper and hand-colored at the press by Shirley Smith, bound in quarter leather in slipcase; 175 copies printed on Zerkall mould-made paper, bound at Smith Settle of Otley in paper-covered boards with linen spine and printed endpapers also designed by Shirley Smith of which this is an unnumbered proof copy, so marked with the Libanus Press blind stamp. Prospectus laid in.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: The Boke of Iford Introduction by Robert Whalley. Marlborough, Wiltshire: Libanus Press, 1993.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Set in monotype Bembo. Cover design by Richard Shirley Smith, title page boarder and eleven drawn illustrations. Perfect bound soft cover edition. Prospectus and sample page laid in.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: My First Alphabet. Published by John Loch, The Market House, Aldbourne, 1994.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Designed by Libanus Press, Marlborough; photoset in monotype Spectrum. Printed and bound by Smith Settle, Otley. First edition. One of 115 unnumbered copies. Frontispiece drawn portrait by Richard Shirley Smith, also 'Aldbourne Bookplate' by Shirley Smith reproduced opposite contents page [Bain no. 254 and North Lee no. 23]. Perfect bound soft cover.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Metamorphoses. Translated and introduced by Mary M. Innes illustrations by Richard Shirley Smith. London: The Folio Society, 1995.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Eight leaves of color reproductions of paintings by Shirley Smith (facingPp. 32, 49, 97, 112, 225, 240, 288 and 305). In addition to the plates there are thirteen tail-pieces (one used twice) and the title-page design, which incorporates the main title and imprint in a pastiche of a classical monumental inscription. Typeset in 13- point Baskerville with Fry's Baskerville for display. Typeset by Gloucester Typesetting Services, printed and bound by The Bath Press on Hamilton Wove and Mohawk Superfine paper and bound by them in quarter leatherette with pale grey cloth sides over-printed in dark green with a drawing by Shirley Smith, after Bernini. Gray slip case. Color prospectus (4Pp.) from The Folio Society for the Ovid laid in.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Ten Letters to Two Young Artists Working in Italy: Juliet Wood & Richard Shirley Smith. Preface by John Montague, introduction by Shirley Smith, edited by Derek Shiel. London: Agenda Editions, 1996.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Designed by Shirley Smith; typeset by Libanus Press, Marlborough; printed and bound by Smith Settle, Otley, West Yorkshire. First edition. Edition limited to 160 copies of which this is no. 105. Shirley Smith signed wood-engraving in chemise envelope (the dedicatory engraving "J. to G.F." from A Point of Departure by Joyce Finzi; Bain no. 11). Quarter bound in tan book cloth, boards illustrated with squeeze of a Roman inscription made by Shirley Smith in Rome. Slipcase.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: The Folio Golden Treasury--The Best Songs and Lyrical Poems in the English Language. London: The Folio Society, 1997.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typeset in Baskerville at The Folio Society and printed at St Edmundsbury Press on Balmoral Book Wove paper bound by Hunter & Foulis, Edinburgh. 'Illustrated with wood engravings by various artists selected by Simon Brett.' Included are engravings by Shirley Smith illustrating sections: 8, 169, 170, 171, 187, 205, 224 (three engravings), 291, 292, 294, 296, 298, 299, 300 (two engravings), 301 (two engravings), 302 (three engravings)––in all 22 engravings, many of which had previously been commissioned for Folio Society books. Bound in quarter leather with cloth sides over-printed with a design by Simon Brett contained in a slip case.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Complete Plays. Edited by Stanley Wells and Gary Taylor; Introduced by Jonathan Bate. London: The Folio Society, 1997.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Set in Baskerville by Oxford University Press, with play titles hand set in Fournier by Speedspools, Edinburgh. Printed at the Bath Press, Bath, on Caxton wove paper and bound by them in Oxford Library Buckram with paper sides printed with designs by Richard Shirley Smith. Eight volumes in two slip cases also decorated by Shirley Smith.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Forbidden Fruit: Selected Tales in Verse. Translated by Guido Waldman Illustrated by Richard Shirley Smith. London: Harvill Press, 1998.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Designed and set in Fournier at Libanus Press, Marlborough, Wiltshire. Printed by Butler and Tanner, Ltd., Selwood Printing, Burgess Hill. Shirley Smith line drawn illustrations [nine full page, two of which are reused for dust jacket, chapter rule, and seven smaller drawings, some of which are used more than once]. Bound in blue book cloth with dust jacket.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Forbidden Fruit: Selected Tales in Verse. Translated by Guido Waldman Illustrated by Richard Shirley Smith. London: Harvill Press, 1998.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Perfect bound paperback copy of the above.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Memoirs Laughing and Dancing Our Way to the Precipice. Translated by Felice Harcourt. London: Harvill Press, 1999.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Tour du Pin Gouvernet, Henriette Lucie Dillon, marquise de, 1770-1853

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 'Cover illustration of Madame de La Tour du Pin by Richard Shirley Smith series design by Libanus Press'. Harvill Press logo by Shirley Smith [Bain no. 264] on title page. Perfect bound soft cover.

did.unittitle: Cat Cuts: A Collection of Engravers' Cats. London: Primrose Hill Press, 1999.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Designed and typeset by Oblong, Otley; printed and bound by Smith Settle, Otley. First edition. Includes three Richard Shirley Smith wood engravings: Benoît Junod bookplate [1983, Bain no. 256, North Lee no. 25], 'Portrait of Pépé' [1980; Bain no. 245], and 'The Artists' Cats', 1981 [Bain no. 252]. Bound in dark blue book cloth with dust jacket.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: The Eclogues. Translated by James Michie. Introduction by Gilbert Highet. Decorations by Richard Shirley Smith. London: The Folio Society, 2000.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typeset in Centaur at the Folio Society; printed by Butler and Tanner, Frome, on Rivoli rag-content paper and bound by them. Frontispiece and 21 other line drawings used for chapter heads, etc. Bound in book cloth with paper sides over-printed with a design by Shirley Smith, contained in a slipcase.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Building Towers, Forming Gardens: Landscaping by Hamilton, Hoare and Beckford. London: St. Barnabas Press, 2002.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: First edition. Designed by Humphrey Stone and printed by BAS Printers, Ltd., Over Wallop, Stockbridge, Hampshire. Limited edition of 150 copies of which this is no. 71 signed on the half title page by Richard Shirley Smith. A set of the four engravings [1989; Bain nos. 285-288] signed and numbered 71/150 contained in a chemise. Color reproductions of four commissioned illustrations by Shirley Smith tipped in. Endpapers reproduce the 1823 map of the Fonthill estate. Bound in patterned yellow book cloth designed by Shirley Smith.

Ian Bain lists this book as Enchanting Paths to Paradise, c. 1989. The title was changed prior to publication in 2002. The four engravings for this project were the last wood engravings executed by Shirley Smith.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Building Towers, Forming Gardens: Landscaping by Hamilton, Hoare and Beckford. London: St. Barnabas Press, 2002.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Without the color reproductions tipped into the limited edition, one of which is reproduced on the cover in color. Signed by Richard Shirley Smith on the half title page. Perfect bound soft binding.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Daily Life in Ancient Rome The People and the City at the Height of the Empire. Edited by Henry T. Rowell Translated from the French by E. O. Lorimer Introduced by Keith Hopkins. London: The Folio Society, 2004.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typeset in Poliphilus and Blado at The Folio Society. Printed at St Edmundsbury Press, Bury St Edmunds, on Clan Book wove paper. Bound by Reallachenmaier, Reutlingen, Germany, in full cloth, over-printed with a design by Richard Shirley Smith. Red paper covered slip case.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Despatches with a wood engraving by Richard Shirley Smith. Durham: Black Cygnet Press, 2006.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 'This further selection from Thais with the frontispiece of the Roman Forum printed from the wood ["Temple of Antoninus & Faustina" Bain no. 8] has been composed in 18- point leaded Baskerville italic, printed on Zerkall mould–made paper in an edition of one hundred copies, and bound in Ann Muir marbled wrappers by Alan Anderson.' Sewn soft binding.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: "Highgrove Florilegium Exhibition." Garden Museum (Summer, 2009)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes drawn vignettes by Richard Shirley Smith from the Florilegium. Perfect bound soft cover.

The Highgrove Florilegium (London: Addison Publications Ltd., 2008–2009) was published for The Prince's Charities Foundation. It is a two–volume fine art facsimile of original watercolors by several botanical artists of plants and trees growing at Highgrove in Gloucestershire, the home of TRH The Prince of Wales and The Duchess of Cornwall. The print run was limited to 175 numbered copies (at £10,950 per copy) with a preface signed by HRH The Prince of Wales. Richard Shirley Smith's vignettes of features from the Highgrove garden were used as endpapers and throughout the text.
A record for this item is also available in the Yale University Library Catalog.

did.unittitle: Engraved and Drawn Bookplates by Richard Shirley Smith

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: All bookplates are matted and boxed, and arranged in the sequence assigned by Brian North Lee, Bookplates of Richard Shirley Smith (2005), as extended. Also recorded are the numbers assigned by Iain Bain, The Wood Engravings of Richard Shirley Smith (1994).

"The tower of boxes" (from a Persian folk tale)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A children's story about a king who attempts to reach the moon by way of a tower of boxes. Written in pen and black ink, in the hand of Shirley Smith (and with his ink stamp at the head of the first leaf).

did.unittitle: "The tower of boxes": slides of collages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 35mm slides of mixed media collages to illustrate the story of "The tower of boxes." The slides are numbered in pen and black ink. Several are also inscribed with the title, and two are inscribed "Dennis Dobson pbr." Shirley Smith illustrated several works published by Dobson in the mid-1960s, but there is no evidence that "The tower of boxes" was ever published.

scopecontent.p: Type specimen book for Arcadian Bembo, Roman, Italic, and Expert typefaces, developed by Tru Typographic Research Unit Limited in association with Monotype Imaging Ltd.. Page 3 includes a reproduction (at a reduced scale) of Richard Shirley Smith's engraving of Pietro Bembo.

did.unittitle: Instructions on the proper mounting of wood engravings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscript note, in the hand of Richard Shirley Smith (to Roger W. Moss?) on how to mount prints with sufficient space in the margins. Accompanied a batch of prints: "There are 13 prints, some numbered & limited, some artist's proofs. Some are the last I have & some are much finer than others ..."
